title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 03 On Mimesis
text:
The Artisans and the Poets

What virtues belong to each class?
What is the first class that Plato discusses?


Oddly enough, in Bk III, Plato leaves off any discussion of what he calls poetry, because even though he is convinced that poetry disrupts the training of the just sole, he cannot say how it does so until he has defined justice. This part of the project takes from Bk III to Bk IVX to do. While his conclusion is that art can disrupt this ideal ordering of the tripartite self, it is not until we get to Bk X to see how this is possible.


Artists, most notably the poets, are often cited as teachers of virtue. Yet, the most they are capable of is imitation. This brings us to the primary argument in Bk X of the Republic. What is this class of thing which poetry belongs to?

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 03 On Mimesis

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 03 On Mimesis
text:
Dorian Mode:

Just leave me the mode that would suitably imitate the tone and rhythm of a courageious person who is active in battle or doing other violent deeds, or who is failing and facing wounds, death, or some other misfortune, and who, in all these circumstances, is fighting off his fate steadily and with self-control.

Mastering the material takes practice.

Watching someone else do something is not the same as doing it yourself.
Keep up with the assignment schedule.
Cramming will not be a helpful way to prepare for the exams in this course.

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 01/02 Introduction
text:
The Elimination of Metaphysics

The traditional disputes of philosophers are, for the most part, as unwar- ranted as they are unfruitful. The surest way to end them is to establish beyond question what should be the purpose and method of a philosophical inquiry. And this is by no means so difficult a task as the history of philoso- phy would lead one to suppose. For if there are any questions which science leaves it to philosophy to answer, a straightforward process of elimination must lead to their discovery. [Alfred Jules Ayer, Language, Truth, and Logic]

â€˜the Absolute enters into, but is itself incapable of, evolution and progressâ€™,

A sentence is meaningful when it is factually significant.
In order to determine whether a sentence is facutally significant?
It must be empirically verifiable

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 01/02 Introduction
text:
What is a good thought?

We need only formulate the criterion which enables us to test whether a sentence expresses a genuine proposition about a matter of fact, and then point out that the sentences under consideration fail to satisfy it. Criterion of Verifiability

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 01/02 Introduction
text:
Ayerâ€™s Attempt

We say that a sentence is factually significant to any given person, if, and only if, he knows how to verify the proposition which it purports to expressâ€”that is, if he knows what observations would lead him, under certain conditions, to accept the proposition as being true, or reject it as being false.

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 03 Introduction
section: Letâ€™s identify the main components of this argument
text:
Letâ€™s identify the main components of this argument

In Bernard Suitsâ€™ The Grasshopper and Return of the Grasshopper, game-play is claimed to be the â€˜ideal of existenceâ€™ and the only activity that could sustain us through the â€˜endless and endlessly boring summerâ€™ of utopia. Christopher Yorke has challenged these claims by way of a constructive dilemma. If these games are sufficiently akin to the games we play, then they are not adequate to the task of rendering immortality tolerable. If these games are importantly different than the games we play, then, in being â€˜unknown and unknowableâ€™, they would characterize a form of life that is importantly different from our own and, so, would be inappropriate objects of social and political aspiration. Against Yorkeâ€™s skepticism, I argue that the games that constitute the ideal of existence are intelligible to us because we already play what the Grasshopper calls â€˜open gamesâ€™. Steffen Borge concedes that utopian games are intelligible, but argues that such games would fail to â€˜grab our minds and imaginationâ€™. In the second half of the paper, I contend, against Borge, that such open games are adequate to the task of sustaining the interest of an immortal community.

text:

If these games are importantly different than the games we play, then, in being â€˜unknown and unknowableâ€™, they would characterize a form of life that is importantly different from our own and, so, would be inappropriate objects of social and political aspiration.

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 03 Introduction
text:
First,

P = These games are like the ones we play.
Q = These games make immortality tolerable.
R = Characterize a form of life that is different from our own.

text:
Consider the sequent:

To save space, we often write an entire form on one line. [p.Â 23]

\(\neg\) P

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 03 Introduction
text:
The Ontological Argument
Letâ€™s identify the main components of this argument.

So, then, no one who understands what God is can conceive that God does not exist; although he says these words in his heart, either without any, or with some, foreign signification. For; God is that than which a greater cannot be conceived. And he who thoroughly understands this assuredly understands that this being so truly exists, that not even in concept can it be nonexistent. Therefore, he who understands that God so exists cannot conceive that he does not exist.

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 03 Introduction
text:
Saint Anselm of Cantebury



.





Italian Monk.
lived from 1033 AD to 1109 AD.
Was exiled from both England and Rome for advocating Church independence from secular authorities.
Most notable for his Ontological Argument.

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 03 Introduction
text:
Formation Rules
We are going to be looking for:

Propositions (Sentences/tf Statements)
Logical Operators (Connect Propositions)
Scope (Which logical operators apply to which propositions)



The formulas of propositional logic have a grammar, and that grammar (or syntax) may be precisely articulated as formation rules. Formation rules define what counts as a formula by giving general directions for assembling formulas out of simple symbols, or characters. They are the rules of grammar for a formal language. In order to state the formation rules for propositional logic, we need first to define the character set for propositional logicâ€”that is, the alphabet and punctuation marks from which the formulas of its language are constructed. We stipulate that a character for the language of propositional logic is anything belonging to one of the following four sets:

For; God is that than which a greater cannot be conceived. And he who thoroughly understands this assuredly understands that this being so truly exists, that not even in concept can it be nonexistent. Therefore, he who understands that God so exists cannot conceive that he does not exist.
